body.div:
March 9, 1916 My dear Mrs. Aldis:
Please do not think that I am very unappreciative if I say that I think I had better refuse all these kind invitations of Mr. Eddy. You see, I shall only arrive in Chicago in time to get ready for your lunch, so that knocks out the morning suggestion. And between your lunch and my lecture in the evening I feel I must get a little rest, after a night on the train, otherwise I shall be no good—these lectures take it out of one horribly. The same remark applies to going out to Mr. Eddy’s after the lecture, as I feel sure I shall then be exhausted and had better go straight home and go to bed. It is very kind of him to suggest this, and I am extremely grateful; but that particular day will be so strenuous and so full of interest and excitement, that I think any more would reduce me to a breaking point. Will you, therefore, make my most grateful excuses?
I think your poem-play, “The Park Bench”, extremely interesting, and to my mind it “gets over” very well in blank verse. Whether or not it would not get over just as well in vers libre is not the point. And whether or not, set on the stage, it would give quite the same impression as regular conversation (which I believe is the question you asked me)—whether people in that walk of life talking apparently naturally in blank verse would seem a little of an anachronism—I don’t know. And, to tell you the truth, I should not care. The thing is most interesting, and extremely well done, and I think that is quite sufficient. And it
may be that you have completely proved your point that plays in metre can still be given. It would be a most interesting experiment, and I shall feel honored to have my things acted on the same evening as this.
I shall see you very soon now. I am going to New York next week, for a Civic Forum Farewell Dinner to Masefield at which I am speaking. I am going directly from New York to Chicago, and Sunday will find me knocking at your door; at 1.30, I believe? Sincerely yours,

div.note: Mr. Eddy could be referring to Arthur Jerome Eddy, a promonent art collector and figure in the Chicago art scene in the early 1900s. At the time of encoding, the encoder could not definently identify who Mr. Eddy refers to.
